review.title: Hybrid Automated Reasoning Tools: from Black-box to Clear-box Integration
review.abstract: Recently, researchers in answer set programming and constraint programming spent significant efforts in the development of hybrid languages and solving algorithms combining the strengths of these traditionally separate fields. These efforts resulted in a new research area: constraint answer set programming (CASP). CASP languages and systems proved to be largely successful at providing efficient solutions to problems involving hybrid reasoning tasks, such as scheduling problems with elements of planning. Yet, the development of CASP systems is difficult, requiring non-trivial expertise in multiple areas. This suggests a need for a study identifying general development principles of hybrid systems. Once these principles and their implications are well understood, the development of hybrid languages and systems may become a well-established and well-understood routine process. As a step in this direction, in this paper we conduct a case study aimed at evaluating various integration schemas of CASP methods.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: The case study carried out in this paper clearly illustrates the influence that integration methods have on the behaviour of hybrid systems. Each integration scheme can be useful and meaningful for a specific area. Therefore, systematic means should be found to facilitate the construction of hybrid systems that support various coupling mechanisms. Establishing clear and flexible API interfaces that allow different types of interaction between the solvers seems to be a necessary step to make the development of hybrid solution systems effective.
